Situation1: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story: I’ve been saving for years, setting aside a little each month, dreaming of the day I could finally perform Hajj. This year, my friends are going, and I have enough saved. The excitement in our group chat is contagious, and my heart aches to join them, fulfilling this pillar of my faith. But as a volunteer at the community center, I’ve just been briefed on new safety protocols. The coordinator emphasized how crucial it is for all of us to be present and vigilant, especially during the upcoming summer programs when the center is busiest. She looked right at me, reminding us that our commitment keeps everyone safe. I feel torn—my faith calls me to Mecca, but my sense of responsibility to the children and families who rely on us weighs heavily. I can’t shake the guilt at the thought of leaving my team short-handed, but the longing to answer the call to Hajj is overwhelming. My mind races, caught between two worlds, each demanding my presence, each pulling at my heart.
